title: The Thieves of Manhattan by Adam Langer {dwg}
description: The famously false memoirs of James Frey may be yesterdayÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s news, but as this funny riff reminds us, literary fakes are as old as literature itself. Ian Minot is an aspiring writer who labors over short stories that seem destined to remain unread. His beautiful Romanian girlfriend, Anya Petrescu, finds success more easilyÃ¢â‚¬â€and leaves Ian for Blade Markham, a bloviating ex-gangbanger whose Ã¢â‚¬Å“so-called memoirÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ is a best-seller. When Ian is approached by ex-editor Jed Roth, who wants Ian to publish JedÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s pulpy tale of book theft and murder as a memoir, then renounce it, itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s a chance for both of them to get revenge: Jed on his former employer, and Ian on the world. Although Langer may be too cute for some (he employs made-up slang in which a penis is a portnoy), he does an engaging job with the hall-of-mirrors plot. And if readers can predict that the book theyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re reading is the one that Ian ends up writing, theyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll never guess the ending. Just when you want a surprising twist, Langer delivers several
